content:
• Tuesday, May 12, 2015
  • NCMI

    National CineMedia gains off earnings, bullish analysis

    • In-theater ad firm National CineMedia (NASDAQ:NCMI) finished up 6% today, charging off an earnings report where it noted an upbeat outlook for Q2 and the rest of 2015.
    • FBR & Co. upgraded the stock to Outperform, with a price target to $17.50: "Maintenance of a modicum of 2015 momentum into 2016, which appears likely, would argue for additional revenue growth that should go straight into dividend hikes that fuel the equity."
    • Benchmark raised its price target on the shares, to $17.31 from $16.81, and maintained a Buy rating. Analyst Mike Hickey reeled off the positives: "Favorable consideration is factored from a significant valuation reset, stabilized CPMs, elevated yield, strong guidance, optimism over forward box office growth and a strong executive team," before noting offsets including ad softness and mobile competition.
    • Shares closed today at $15.80 and the company features a forward dividend yield of 5.9%. It's owned by theater circuits Regal, AMC and Cinemark along with smaller partners.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:35 PM
  • VSLR

    Vivint -8.5%; installations top guidance, but Q2 sales outlook light

    • Vivint (NYSE:VSLR) installed 46MW of solar systems in Q1, +131% Y/Y and topping guidance of 40MW-42MW. The company is also reiterating full-year guidance of 290MW-310MW.. However, Q2 revenue guidance of $14M-$15M is below a $17.1M consensus; installations are expected to rise to 63MW-67MW.
    • Business metrics: Solar bookings rose 90% Y/Y in Q1 to 50MW, and installations 100% to 6,426 (brings the total to 42,146). Estimated nominal contracted payments rose by $174M Q/Q to ~$1.2B, and estimated retained value by $79M to $560M. Estimated retained value per watt fell to $2.05 from $2.11 at the end of Q4. Cumulative MW installed is now at 274MW.
    • Financials: GAAP costs/expenses rose 74% Y/Y to $58.2M (compares with 173% rev. growth); cost of revenue totaled $24.3M, sales/marketing spend $6.4M, G&A $18.6M, and R&D $582K. Vivint ended Q1 with $194.2M in cash, $12.2M in restricted cash, and $122.5M in long-term debt.
    • Shares have fallen to $13.70 AH. They were up 62% YTD going into earnings.
    • Q1 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 6:24 PM
  • AES

    AES Corp. in 60M-share secondary offering

    • AES Corp. (NYSE:AES) -3.3% AH after announcing a secondary public offering of 60M common shares by a subsidiary controlled by China Investment Corp., and the concurrent repurchase of 20M shares.
    • Following completion of the offering, AES expects that the selling stockholder will have fully sold its stake in the company.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:54 PM
  • Z

    Zillow higher after resuming trading; Market Leader weighs on sales

    • After coming off a halt, Zillow (NASDAQ:Z) is up 1.8% AH in the wake of its Q1 report. In spite of a Q1 revenue miss, the company is reiterating full-year revenue and adjusted EBITDA guidance of $690M and $80M-$85M (provided on April 14).
    • The Market Leader real estate CRM software unit (acquired by Trulia in 2013) was a weak spot in Q1: Its sales fell 11% Y/Y to $13.6M. Display ad sales were also light, rising only 5% on a pro forma basis (i.e. counting both Zillow and Trulia's full numbers) to $25.6M. Yelp, LinkedIn, and others have reported soft Q1 display ad sales, while often blaming industry adoption of programmatic (automated) ad-buying platforms that have depressed prices.
    • Core real estate services revenue was stronger, rising 54% to $113.4M. Mortgage services revenue rose 33% to $10M.
    • Business metrics: Zillow had 103,415 Premier Agent advertisers at the end of Q1 - that figure includes Trulia agents. Premier Agent ARPA was $354; it was $359 for Zillow proper in Q4. Following the end of the ListHub deal, Zillow says it now receives 100% of real estate listings directly. March unique visitors totaled nearly 140M, and close to 2/3 of Zillow brand usage now occurs on mobile.
    • Pro forma adjusted EBITDA more than doubled Y/Y to $24.5M. $12.5M worth of acquisition costs were recorded, as were $25.1M worth of restructuring costs - Zillow/Trulia announced job cuts after their merger closed in February.
    • Q1 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 5:44 PM | 4 Comments
  • SBLK

    Star Bulk Carriers to launch $150M share offering

    • Star Bulk Carriers (NASDAQ:SBLK) -1.3% AH after announcing plans for a public offering of $150M of its common shares.
    • SBLK says it plans to use the proceeds for its newbuilding program and general corporate purposes, including additions to working capital, capital expenditures, repayment of debt or the financing of possible acquisitions and investments.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:58 PM | 3 Comments
  • GDDY

    GoDaddy drops in spite of revenue beat, strong sales guidance

    • GoDaddy's (NYSE:GDDY) Q1 revenue of $376.3M beat a $374.5M consensus. The company is also guiding for Q2 revenue of $390M-$395M (above a $390.7M consensus at the midpoint) and full-year revenue of $1.595B-$1.605B (above a $1.59B consensus). Worth noting: Initial post-IPO analyst estimates are often conservative.
    • Key numbers: Bookings rose 13.7% Y/Y in Q1 to $498.7M (well above revenue), and (though EPS was negative) unlevered free cash flow 70.7% to $85.1M. Adjusted EBITDA rose 17.8% to $93.9M; Q2 adjusted EBITDA guidance is at $75M-$78M, and full-year guidance at $322M-$327M.
    • Business performance: Domain name revenue +10.4% Y/Y to $199.2M. Web hosting/site-building service revenue +21.2% to $140.2M. Business app revenue +53.3% to $36.9M. Customers rose by 400K Q/Q and 1.2M Y/Y to 13.1M. ARPU rose by $1 Q/Q and $10 Y/Y to $115. International revenue rose 23.4% Y/Y to $95.9M (25% of total revenue).
    • Financials: Total costs/expenses rose 12% to $396.8M (less than rev. growth of 17.5%) - cost of revenue was $137.2M, depreciatio $67.6M was spent on R&D, $50.7M on marketing/advertising, and $56.7M on "customer care". Capex was a modest $8.2M. GoDaddy ended Q1 with $1.27B in net debt and a $1.34B deferred revenue balance.
    • GDDY -1.9% AH to $26.27. Shares rose 4.2% in regular trading ahead of the Q1 report, and also rallied yesterday thanks to bullish analyst coverage.
    • Q1 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 4:51 PM | 1 Comment
  • TUBE

    TubeMogul up 13% on revenue beat, upside sales guidance

    • Online ad platform provider TubeMogul (NASDAQ:TUBE) has jumped 13.4% in after-hours trade following a Q1 report where revenues increased 38% and gross profit grew 39%.
    • Total spend -- which includes media purchase costs and TubeMogul fees -- was $71.3M, up 48% Y/Y. The company's loss widened significantly, though, as operating costs rose 71%.
    • Revenue breakout: Platform Direct, $14.3M (up 55%); Platform Services, $16M (up 25.3%).
    • The company guided to Q2 revenues of $38M-$40M (vs. an expected $37M) and adjusted EBITDA of -$3M to -$1M (vs. an expected -$2.8M), and full-year revenues of $149M-$157M (the high side of an expected $149M) and EBITDA of -$15M to -$7M, in line.
    • Conference call at 5 p.m. ET.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:47 PM
  • ICCC

    ImmuCell reports Q1 results

    • ImmuCell (NASDAQ:ICCC): Q1 EPS of $0.15
    • Revenue of $3.1M (+47.6% Y/Y)
    • Shares +5.7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:46 PM
  • HDP

    Hortonworks up 14.7% on Q1 beat, strong guidance

    • In addition to beating Q1 estimates, Hortonworks (NASDAQ:HDP) is guiding for Q2 revenue of $22.5M-$23.5M (above a $20.3M consensus) and full-year revenue of $94M-$97M (well above an $85.7M consensus).
    • Billings: Q1 gross billings totaled $28.1M, +99% Y/Y, above revenue of $22.8M, and in-line with guidance of $27M-$29M. Billings are expected to rise to $35.5M-$37.5M in Q2, and $153M-$159M for the whole of 2015 (+79% at the midpoint and improved by $3M over prior guidance). Q1 billings growth helped fuel a 117% increase in Hortonworks' deferred revenue balance to $68.3M.
    • 105 support subscription customers were added for Hortonworks' Hadoop big data/analytics software platform. That's up from seasonally strong Q4's 99 and brings the total base above 400 (up over 200% Y/Y).
    • Financials: Support subscription revenue +216% Y/Y to $13.6M; professional services +116% to $9.2M. Gross margin (non-GAAP) rose to 51% from 45% a year ago. GAAP operating expenses rose 126% to $51.8M - $27.8M was spent on sales/marketing, $15M on R&D, and $9.1M on G&A.
    • Hortonworks has jumped to $24.99 AH. Shares rose 5.2% in regular trading ahead of earnings.
    • Q1 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 4:24 PM
  • IDXG

    PDI up 16.5% on solid beat, upside 2015 guidance

    • PDI (PDII) has jumped 16.5% after hours as it posted a loss significantly better than expected and beat revenues in Q1.
    • Gross profit increased 49% to $7.2M. Revenue breakout: Commercial services, $36.2M (up 14%); Interpace diagnostics, $2.12M (new).
    • The company guided to 2015 total revenue of $136M-$140M, vs. an expected $135.95M, and to an adjusted operating loss of $17M-$19M.
    • Conference call at 4:30 p.m. ET.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:19 PM
  • GEVO

    Gevo beats by $0.32, misses on revenue

    • Gevo (NASDAQ:GEVO): Q1 EPS of -$0.88 beats by $0.32.
    • Revenue of $5.9M misses by $0.2M.
    • Shares +13.5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:17 PM
  • SES

    Synthesis Energy reports FQ3 results

    • Synthesis Energy (SYMX): FQ3 EPS of -$0.05
    • Revenue of $2.8M (-61.1% Y/Y)
    • Shares +7.5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:16 PM | 1 Comment
  • VSLR

    Vivint Solar misses by $0.19, beats on revenue

    • Vivint Solar (NYSE:VSLR): Q1 EPS of -$0.57 misses by $0.19.
    • Revenue of $9.54M (+172.6% Y/Y) beats by $1.48M.
    • Shares -9% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:13 PM | 4 Comments
  • GDDY

    GoDaddy EPS of -$0.34

    • GoDaddy (NYSE:GDDY): Q1 EPS of -$0.34 may not be comparable to consensus of $0.35.
    • Revenue of $376.3M (+17.5% Y/Y)
    • Shares +2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:08 PM | 5 Comments
  • I

    Intelsat off 2.4% as Morgan Stanley downgrades on growth concern

    • Intelsat (NYSE:I) is closing down 2.4% after Morgan Stanley downgraded shares to Underweight, from Equal Weight, pointing to the risk of relying on growing revenue to improve free cash flow.
    • And that's a problem because the company's guiding to a second straight year of declining revenues, and MS see sales declining 4.9% and 2.2% for the next two years. High fixed costs mean that cash flow improvement will depend on a return to growth.
    • Along with elevated leverage, that free cash flow pressure "creates refinancing risks in the medium term."
    • MS set a price target of $10 on Intelsat shares; the stock just closed at $11.66.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:03 PM
  • VRTX

    Ad Comm votes 12 - 1 in favor of approval for Vertex's Orkambi

    • The FDA's Pulmonary-Allergy Advisory Committee votes 12 - 1 supporting the regulatory approval of Vertex Pharmaceuticals' (VRTX) Orkambi (lumacaftor/ivacaftor) for the treatment of cystic fibrosis patients with the F508del mutation. It voted 13 - 0 that the product is safe.
    • Previously: Positive Ad Comm vote for Vertex Pharma's Orkambi uncertain (May 12)
    • Previously: Ad Comm review approaches for Vertex's combo pill for cystic fibrosis; positive vote may be a challenge (May 8)
    • Shares are up 7% after hours on robust volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:48 PM | 2 Comments
  • AOL

    Not the old AOL: Verizon purchase all about ads

    • After earnings last week, AOL CEO Tim Armstrong pointed out how programmatic ads were key to the company's growth -- and now they're the key to its $4.4B acquisition by a video-focused Verizon (NYSE:VZ).
    • For Verizon, the timing and focus will be on an upcoming video service that is likely to focus on shorter clips rather than long shows (in keeping with their stated target of mobile-viewing millennials) and would combine key assets in the OnCue service it bought from Intel and the ad-insertion tech that AOL provides. The benefit would come in faster, better ad sales. AOL's Platforms unit grew revenues 21% to $279.8M.
    • Wells Fargo's Jennifer Fritzsche points out the difference between Verizon's strategy and that of AT&T: "While T believes there is a greater need to own more physical infrastructure (through DTV), VZ is building up more assets to strengthen its 'mobile first' OTT initiative -– with advertising playing a key role."
    • Verizon's approach to video is cheaper, too, notes Andrew Dowell in comparing a 4.4B AOL deal with a $49B DirecTV deal: "Verizon is going after millennials. AT&T has its eye on their parents."
    • Meanwhile, Macquarie has downgraded Verizon to Underperform, from Neutral, with a new price target of $45. Shares today are trading down 0.4% to $49.61; AOL is up 18.5% to $50.47.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:44 PM | 9 Comments

  • Notable tech gainers/decliners: EBIX, QIHU, JD, VIPS, MOSY, MOBL, SLTD

    • Today's notable tech gainers include insurance software/data exchange provider Ebix (EBIX +5%), Chinese polysilicon maker Daqo (DQ +6.9%), networking SRAM maker MoSys (MOSY +7.7%), enterprise mobility management software firm MobileIron (MOBL +6.3%), U.S. solar installer Solar3D (SLTD +4.3%), and Korean analog/mixed-signal chipmaker MagnaChip (MX +5.3%).
    • Notable decliners include Chinese online retailers JD.com (JD -4.4%) and Vipshop (VIPS -5%), Chinese Internet mini-conglomerate Qihoo (QIHU -4.6%), and cloud online learning software provider 2U (TWOU -5.6%). The Nasdaq is down 0.2%.
    • Daqo is now up 11% since last Friday's mixed Q1 report. Ebix is up 18% since delivering a Q1 beat last Friday. MobileIron's gains come after the company named well-traveled tech vet Simon Biddiscombe its interim CFO. Solar3D is rallying after issuing a PR that sings the praises a of an upbeat Bernstein report on solar cost declines.
    • Qihoo and JD are more than reversing the Monday gains seen amid a Chinese Internet stock rally. 2U has now fully given back the gains seen last week following its Q1 beat.
    • Previously covered: Rackspace, Everyday Health, magicJack, WidePoint, LivePerson, YY, STMicroelectronics, ChipMOS, iDreamSky, Leidos, Photronics
     
     
     
     
    | 3:12 PM | 2 Comments
  • BURG

    Chanticleer Holdings +10% in sudden burst

    • Chanticleer Holdings (HOTR) shoots up 10.1% on strong volume to carve out a new 52-week high of $3.15.
    • Shares moved higher after SA contributor John Ford called the stock deeply undervalued.
    • Chanticleer is up 76.4% YTD
     
     
     
     
    | 3:10 PM
  • PLAB

    Photronics up 7.2% after guidance hike

    • Photronics (NASDAQ:PLAB) now expects FQ2 revenue of $127M and EPS of $0.11-$0.12, favorable to prior guidance ranges of $121M-$128M and $0.04-$0.09. Consensus was at $126.2M and $0.08.
    • The photomask maker cites "increased demand for advanced memory photomasks and stronger shipments of FPD masks," as well as "strong operational execution." FPD (large-size) photomasks often carry higher ASPs.
    • Shares are within striking distance of a 52-week high of $9.38.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:46 PM
  • RUBI

    Rubicon up 6.1% after Verizon/AOL deal, self-serve platform launch

    • The Rubicon Project (NYSE:RUBI) has joined client Rocket Fuel in rallying after Verizon announced it's buying AOL for $4.4B, thereby sparking hopes other online ad tech plays (particularly ones that enable programmatic/automated ad buys) will be acquired.
    • Also possibly helping Rubicon: The company has launched Seller Cloud Self-Serve, a solution that allows independent Web publishers and app developers to sell inventory through Rubicon's automated online ad exchange to local/small businesses, ad agencies, and ad resellers.
    • Rubicon argues the solution enables automated direct ad buys that are typically smaller than the minimum ad spend requirements of premium sellers, and thus addresses a U.S. market for automated local digital ad spend that (per Borrell Associates) is expected to more than double this year to $5B, and continue growing rapidly over the next several years.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:39 PM
  • MDR

    McDermott cuts 1,700 jobs amid Q1 loss, revenue drop

    • McDermott International (MDR -4.1%) says it has eliminated ~1,700 jobs, mostly skilled labor jobs in its global fabrication yards, as it reports a smaller than expected Q1 loss but an 8.8% Y/Y decline in revenues.
    • MDR attributes some of the financial losses to seasonal weather problems and to project delays caused by third-party companies.
    • MDR says its backlog as of March 31 was $3.75B, compared to $3.6B on Dec. 31; of the latest backlog, about half was related to offshore operations and the other half to subsea operations; Q1 order intake totaled $698M.
    • Despite the losses, MDR says it is in a strong position moving forward with several new contracts in the Middle East and South America, despite the ongoing industry problems with low oil and gas prices.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:32 PM | 2 Comments
  • IPHI

    InPhi up 4% after target hike, IBD plug

    • InPhi (NYSE:IPHI) is making fresh 52-week highs after Northland Securities hiked its target by $5 to $27, and IBD provided the telecom and networking analog/mixed-signal chipmaker with favorable coverage.
    • With the help of an April 28 Q1 beat, shares are now up 83% from an October low of $12.41. They respectively trade for 23x and 19x 2015E and 2016E EPS.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:22 PM | 1 Comment
  • MU

    Drexel Hamilton downgrades Micron; shares -2.6%

    • Believing Samsung's aggressive efforts to gain share could hurt Micron's (NASDAQ:MU) ASPs and margins, Drexel Hamilton has downgraded the memory giant to Hold.
    • The sell-side has been battling for some time over the impact of Samsung's DRAM/NAND expansion efforts. Bears have argued Samsung's spending will put an end to the strong margin growth Micron has seen in recent years (particularly for DRAM); bulls have argued Samsung would only hurt itself if it disrupted the improved DRAM supply/demand balance seen following industry consolidation, and will thus refrain.
    • Cleveland Research offered cautious remarks on Micron last week. Jefferies defended the company; though admitting DRAM pricing was weaker than expected in Q1, it sees the industry responding with corrective supply changes, and forecasts Micron's cost structure will improve at a faster pace than peers as it ramps 20nm DRAM production.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:13 PM | 60 Comments
  • ADTM

    Adaptive Medias up 30% after record Q1 revenues

    • Programmatic-ad firm Adaptive Medias (OTCPK:ADTM) has climbed to a 30.4% gain so far after posting record Q1 revenues despite a wider loss as the company took on millions more in stock compensation expense.
    • Revenues of $1.17M were up 60% Y/Y in large part due to last summer's acquisition of Media Graph.
    • Adjusted EBITDA of -$6.3M was a wider loss than Q4's -$2.8M and Q3's -$3.1M, as the company took a one-time settlement cost of $3.7M. Excluding that, EBITDA improved sequentially.
    • Previously: Adaptive Medias agrees to $4.5M in private-placement sales (May. 05 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:07 PM
  • OREX

    Then, again, maybe Contrave doesn't prevent heart attacks

    • Small cap Orexigen Therapeutics (OREX -7%) slumps on modestly higher volume on the news that the 9,000-patient clinical trial, The Light Study, evaluating its obesity drug Contrave's (buproprion/naltrexone) effects on cardiovascular (CV) outcomes has been terminated based on the recommendation of the Executive Steering Committee chaired by the Cleveland Clinic's Dr. Steven Nissen. The post-approval study was required to determine if a suspected 40% increase in CV risk in patients receiving Contrave could be ruled out.
    • The precise reason for stopping the trial is unknown, but there was a significant dust-up in March when Orexigen disclosed interim results based on only 25% of the expected data from the trial that showed Contrave may prevent heart attacks. The Cleveland Clinic, Takeda Pharmaceutical (Orexigen's marketing partner) and the FDA all cried foul saying that Orexigen not only violated the terms of the data access agreement but jeopardized the remainder of the trial.
    • To make matters worse, data at the 50% point, released by the Executive Committee, show that Contrave's CV benefit observed at the 25% juncture declined to the point where it was not longer statistically significant. Since Contrave elevates blood pressure, there was a real possibility that taking drug actually increased CV risk had the study gone to completion (allowing time for high blood pressure-related adverse events).
    • Orexigen says that a new CV outcomes trial will begin later this year. Interested parties will need to be patient. The target completion date is 2022.
    • Previously: Orexigen's Contrave data release may have not have been a good idea (March 3)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:52 PM | 17 Comments
  • VHC

    VirnetX up 3.8%, recovering losses seen after USPTO ruling

    • After opening lower, VirnetX (NYSEMKT:VHC) has recovered a large chunk of its Monday afternoon losses. Yesterday's decline came after the USPTO's Patent Trial & Appeal Board (PTAT) ruled 26 of the 30 claims in VirnetX's '697 patent (one of the VPN patents asserted against Apple - USPTO filing) are unpatentable.
    • 4 months ago, the USPTO terminated an inter partes review of VirnetX patent claims that was filed by Microsoft. Both companies requested the termination following VirnetX's settlement with the software giant.
    • Yesterday: VirnetX hires IP monetization firm; shares drop 6.4%
     
     
     
     
    | 1:52 PM | 1 Comment
  • LDOS

    Leidos -8.2%; Q1 results beat estimates, but backlog falls 15%

    • Leidos' (NYSE:LDOS) Q1 revenue of $1.24B topped a $1.2B consensus (per Thompson/First Call), and EPS of $0.65 topped a $0.60 consensus (per Bloomberg). However, backlog fell 15% Y/Y to $7.5B, with funded backlog falling 11% to $2.8B. Backlog was down 16% Y/Y at the end of Q4.
    • Also: New business bookings totaled $891M, +4% Y/Y but only good for a 0.72 book-to-bill ratio. Full-year guidance for revenue of $4.6B-$5B and EPS of $2.20-$2.45 is affirmed.
    • National Security Solutions revenue fell 9% Y/Y in Q1 to $862M; Leidos blames "the drawdown of overseas U.S. military forces, reductions in defense and U.S. Government spending resulting from budget cuts, and higher competition resulting in lower contract awards." Health and Engineering revenue rose 3% to $385M.
    • Op. margin fell to 3% from 6.6% a year ago. Leidos ended FQ1 with $377M in cash, and $1.2B in long-term debt.
    • Q1 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 1:22 PM
  • ASH

    Ashland -4.3% as Jana Partners exits its stake

    • Ashland (ASH -4.3%) slides as Jana Partners discloses that it no longer has a stake in the specialty chemicals company, after the activist hedge fund previously held an 8.4% stake.
    • Jana had revealed a significant stake in April 2013 and pushed for the company to do more to boost value for shareholders; shares have since climbed by about two-thirds, and the fund successfully pushed ASH to sell its water technologies business last summer for $1.35B.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:59 PM

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers:  PNX +21%.  OTC:AMCO +16%. PRSC +14%. CALL +13%. RARE +11%. FMSA +11%. HI +11%. GEVO +10%.THLD +10%. SPPI +10%.
    • Losers:  NOR -27%.  OHGI -19%.  SRT -16%. JOBS -14%. LPSN  -12%. FNJN -12%. FMD -11%. EGL -11%. KNDI -11%.  OTC:MEIL -10%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:49 PM | 2 Comments
  • VRTX

    Positive Ad Comm vote for Vertex Pharma's Orkambi uncertain

    • The hoped-for thumbs up from the FDA's Pulmonary-Allergy Advisory Committee supporting approval of Vertex Pharmaceuticals' (VRTX) Orkambi (lumacaftor/ivacaftor) looks somewhat shaky at this point. The committee admits that the FDA was a "bit hasty" on the study design by not including a comparison to Kalydeco (ivacaftor) alone. Consequently, there are doubts from Committee members as to Orkambi's superiority over Kalydeco. Another member reminds the group that the trial design was recommended by the FDA so the company and patients should not be penalized by the delay from another study.
    • The Committee will vote later today. It may be too close to call.
    • Previously: Ad Comm review approaches for Vertex's combo pill for cystic fibrosis; positive vote may be a challenge (May 8)
     
     
     
     
    | 12:40 PM | 2 Comments
  • DSKY

    iDreamSky -7.5%; SA author questions accounting, sees 68% downside

    • "I believe DSKY is a 'walking zombie' Chinese JOBS act IPO experiencing inevitable decline with serious accounting and financial statement integrity issues," says The Pump Stopper in the first sentence of a bearish column on the Chinese mobile game publisher. He gets more critical from there.
    • The author asserts it has been years since iDreamSky delivered a hit game, and that the company badly needs new hit titles due to the rapid pace at which usage for popular Chinese games declines. Recent titles Cookie Run and Monument Valley are believed to be generating minimal revenue and suffering from widespread piracy.
    • The author blames iDreamSky's top-line pressures on mobile gaming platform/app store consolidation - Tencent remains an 800-lb. gorilla in the Chinese gaming market - and intensifying competition from both Chinese and foreign game developers, with the latter increasingly launching games without the help of local publishers.
    • Regarding accounting, The Pump Stopper observes major discrepancies between the revenue and profit figures in iDreamSky's Chinese (SAIC) and SEC filings. "I tried to call DSKY repeatedly but it appears to be impossible to get someone from their internal IR on the phone so I was not able to answer this question. I look forward to DSKY providing whatever their explanation is..."
    • Also criticized: The background of CFO Jun Zhou, a dual-class share structure that limits the voting rights of U.S. investors, and the use of an IR firm known for promoting Chinese companies that have faced fraud allegations. Shares have plunged towards $8.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:21 PM | 6 Comments
  • X

    U.S. Steel higher as bull case presented by Morgan Stanley's Kurtz

    • U.S. Steel (X +2.2%) racks up solid gains after Morgan Stanley analyst Evan Kurtz comes out pounding the table for the stock.
    • Expectations have reset lower and guidance is now achievable, Kurtz writes, after the company lowered its 2015 EBITDA guidance to $700M-$900M from $1.1B-$1.4B and removed a major overhang on the stock; Kurtz believes the new guidance is realistic and attainable.
    • Shares are correlated with steel prices and industry utilization, both of which are set to improve, Kurtz says; flat-rolled steel prices are bottoming, imports are falling, industry capacity utilization is rising, and service centers are closer to ending destocking.
    • Kurtz also anticipates a flat-rolled trade case filing in the near future involving cold-rolled and/or coated sheet, and the possibility of U.S. trade enforcement reforms that would make anti-dumping cases easier to pursue represents a bull case option.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:21 PM | 3 Comments
  • BBSI

    Barrett Business Services crumbles after SEC initiates probe

    • Barrett Business Sevice (BBSI -32.7%) craters after the company discloses in a new filing that it's under investigation by the SEC.

  • IMOS

    ChipMOS lower following EPS beat, soft Q2 sales guidance

    • Though ChipMOS (IMOS -2.1%) slightly beat Q1 EPS estimates (revenue was already known via monthly sales reports), it's guiding for Q2 revenue to be flat to down by a low-single digit % Q/Q. The 2-analyst consensus (possibly outdated given the Q2 guidance given by many chipmakers) is for revenue to rise 9% Q/Q to $182.2M.
    • Financials: Q1 gross margin was 23.3%, -190 bps Q/Q but +350 bps Y/Y and towards the high end of a 21%-24% guidance range (lifted EPS). Q2 GM guidance is at 20%-24%. R&D spend was flat Y/Y at $5.5M, G&A fell by $100K to $5.5M, and sales/marketing fell by $100K to $0.8M. Capex totaled $32.3M (19% of revenue)
    • Business performance: Capacity utilization fell to 72% from 81% in seasonally strong Q4 and 77$ a year ago. The chip testing ops accounted for 23% of revenue, chip assembly 31%, LCD driver test/assembly 26%, and wafer bumping 20%. Large-panel LCD driver demand was strong; small-panel driver and DRAM/flash demand was softer.
    • Also: 1) 500K shares were repurchased, and net debt cut by $7.1M. 2) ChipMOS ended Q1 with $518.4M in cash, and $273.6M in bank loans. 3) The company says it "will continue to act conservatively with regards to our inventory management, CapEx spending and our operating expenses."
    • Q1 results, PR

    STMicro +4.6%; company exploring options for digital ops

    • STMicroelectronics (NYSE:STM) has used its 2015 investor day to state it's exploring options to cut losses at its Digital Product Group (DPG), a division that makes set-top ICs, image sensors, and embedded processors (among other products). "This problem needs to be fixed and we will fix it," says CEO Carlo Bozotti.
    • DPG's revenue fell 27% Y/Y in Q1 to $207M (12% of total revenue); STM blamed a drop legacy sales related to the shuttered ST-Ericsson JV, along with declining image sensor and low-end set-top IC sales. OmniVision and Sony provide tough competition in the image sensor; Broadcom is a fierce rival in the set-top IC space.
    • DPG's performance led STMicro's broader Embedded Processing Solutions (EPS) segment (34% of total revenue, also covers microcontrollers and memory chips) to report a Q1 op. loss of $64M (improved from -$82M a year earlier). STMicro stated on its Q1 CC (transcript) it's working to cut costs within EPS, primarily via DPG.
    • The European chipmaker has also guided today for Q2 revenue and gross margin to hit the midpoints of the guidance ranges set in its April 30 Q1 report. Shares are recovering a portion of their big post-earnings losses.

  • PTIE

    Pain Therapeutics' oral oxycodone successful in abuse deterrent study; shares rise

    • An FDA Category 3 Human Abuse Potential Study with Pain Therapeutics' (NASDAQ:PTIE) Remoxy (oxycodone) Extended-Release Capsules CII showed that both intact and chewed Remoxy was less "liked" than immediate-release oxycodone as measured by the two primary endpoints of Drug Liking and Drug High. The Abuse Potential study was conducted in non-dependent recreational opioid users, per FDA guidelines.
    • Remoxy is an oral, long-acting oxycodone gelatin capsule that is being developed by PTIE under a 2002 agreement with Durect (NASDAQ:DRRX). It is formulated with the Durect's ORADUR technology, which uses a high viscosity base component to provide controlled release of the active ingredient over 12 - 24 hours.
    • PTIE will host a conference call today at 4:30 pm ET to discuss its progress with its drug candidates and to field questions.
    • PTIE shares are up 31% premarket on light volume.

  • MTEM

    Threshold Pharma's evofosfamide Fast Track'd for pancreatic cancer; shares rise

    • Threshold Pharmaceuticals (THLD) announces that the FDA has designated evofosfamide, in combination with gemcitabine, for Fast Track review for treatment-naive patients with metastatic or locally advanced unresectable pancreatic cancer. This is the second Fast Track tag for the drug candidate. In November 2014 the FDA granted it for the treatment, in combination with doxorubicin, of advanced soft tissue sarcoma.
    • Evofosfamide (TH-302) is an investigational hypoxia-activated prodrug which is activated under tumor hypoxic (low oxygen) conditions which typify many cancers. Low oxygen levels in solid tumors are due to insufficient blood supply as a result of abnormal vasculature.
    • Threshold has a global license and co-development agreement for evofosfamide with Merck KGaA (OTCPK:MKGAF) (OTCPK:MKGAY), which includes an option for Threshold to co-commercialize it in the U.S.
    • Fast Track status provides for more frequent interactions with the FDA review team and a rolling review of the New Drug Application (NDA).
    • THLD is up 17% premarket on robust volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:53 AM
